Abstract:
Background: In our study, the aim was to test a novel approach for the assessment of patient‐reported outcomes (PROs), by comparing the two most commonly used instruments‐the MRI and the SF‐36 Health Survey‐with the Patient Global Impression of Severity (PGI‐S) scale and with each other in a group of breast cancer patients during their pre‐ and post‐opertive stay in the hospital. Methods: We consecutively enrolled fifty women affected by invasive breast carcinoma undergoing radical mastectomy and selected forty breast cancer patients without mastectomy (BC). The MRI and the SF‐36 survey were administered pre‐operatively and the patient's status was evaluated by the PGIS scale post‐operatively. The SF‐36, the MRI and PGIS questionnaires were repeated at the seventh‐day follow‐up in BC patients. Results: The mean and standard deviation of the SF‐36 scores at pre‐operative were very similar between the groups of patients undergoing or not surgery, with the exception of the mean difference of the “Emotional Role Limitations” score (MRI 24.9, S.d. = 41.5 vs SF‐36 44.5, S.d. = 27.28) which showed a tendency toward deterioration in the MRI group (p=0.01) that was confirmed by the SF‐36 score (MRI 42/SF‐36 56, p=0.002). These differences were reversed after surgery, when the mean and the standard deviation of the SF‐36 scores were more elevated in the MRI group. The PGI‐S score was higher than the SF‐36 in both groups of patients and was not related to any of the SF‐36 domains before surgery, while it was significantly better than the SF‐36 scores in MRI patients at the follow‐up. Abstract:
Background: There is a lack of studies examining the use of patient activation to enhance engagement in self‐management among patients with chronic low back pain. The use of patient activation as the central framework for a nurse‐led program may facilitate patient engagement in behavior changes that improve self‐management and consequently, outcomes. Methods: The proposed study will use a randomized controlled trial to test the proposed intervention. 60 patients with non‐specific chronic low back pain will be screened for inclusion and randomly assigned to one of four intervention groups: 1) Self‐management intervention; 2) Self‐management plus health behavior change counseling; 3) Self‐management plus nursing coaching; and 4) Control (usual care). Each intervention group will receive a 6‐week group self‐management program. The intervention groups will receive either three coaching or counseling sessions, while the control condition will not receive any intervention. Pre‐post measures will be used to assess differences in patient engagement in self‐management. Changes in self‐management behavior and outcomes will be measured by questionnaires and a qualitative interview with four patients from each intervention group. The effect of the intervention on patient engagement in self‐management will be analyzed using repeated measures analysis. The effect on self‐management behavior and outcomes will be analyzed using structural equation modeling. Discussion: The proposed research will provide important information on the implementation and effectiveness of patient activation as a framework for nurse‐led behavioral interventions in chronic low back pain. We expect the interventions to significantly improve patients engagement in self‐management behavior and enhance clinical outcomes such as self‐efficacy and pain impact. The proposed research may have implications for the development of evidence‐based, patient‐centered nursing interventions for chronic pain.
groundtruth: Great! Now, for the second study arm, we could have participants engage in a nurse-led evidence-based web-enabled group self-management class for 6 weeks. This will allow us to evaluate the effectiveness of the self-management program alone in improving patient activation and outcomes related to chronic low back pain. What do you think?

Excellent! For the third study arm, we could combine the self-management program with health behavior change counseling. Participants in this arm would engage in the same self-management program for 6 weeks and also receive three telephone-based health behavioral change counseling sessions based on the principles and practices of motivational interviewing. This combined intervention aims to further enhance patient activation and engagement in self-management strategies. What are your thoughts on this?

Perfect! Here are the full study arms for the trial:

1. No Intervention: Control
Participant Group/Arm: Participants receive no intervention.

2. Active Comparator: Self-management program (SMP)
Participant Group/Arm: Participants engage in a nurse-led evidence-based web-enabled group self-management class for 6 weeks.
Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral: Self-management program
- An evidence-based 6-week SMP led by a registered nurse. The SMP is based on the Arthritis Self-Management Program and the Chronic Disease Self-Management Program.

3. Experimental: Self-management program (SMP) with Health Behavior Change Counseling (HBCC)
Participant Group/Arm: Participants engage in a nurse-led evidence-based web-enabled group self-management class for 6 weeks and receive three telephone-based health behavioral change counseling sessions based on the principles and practices of motivational interviewing.
Intervention/Treatment:
- Behavioral: Health Behavior Change Counseling
  * A telephone-based intervention employing principles and practices of motivational interviewing.
- Behavioral: Self-management program
  * An evidence-based 6-week SMP led by a registered nurse. The SMP is based on the Arthritis Self-Management Program and the Chronic Disease Self-Management Program.
